history.content:
Yes. Even after taking 189 it is still worth it. Don't think 127 is just preparation of 189, it is also a valuable class itself.

110 should be fine after MATH 54. For EECS127, you might want to take EE16B(Or 110 for sure) after 54 since it involves many properties/spectral theorem/pca/regression/control etc. stuff (ee applications of lin alg). Only after taking EE16B can you fully digest it.

 

I strongly recommend you take at least two linear alg courses before 189 even if you get an easy A in math 54 (maybe even A+ because there's a difference between familiar with material and mathematical maturity). Math54 + EE16B, EE16AB, Math54 + Math 110 should all be fine. Fall semester CS189 are usually math intensive than springs, and exams are proof instead of many multiple choices like in spring, and you should be very very familiar with SVD, PCA(ee16b, Spectral Theorem(ee16b), Regression(ee16a) Trace etc. Lower div linalg courses are more of the calculating side, but you also need a serious proof perspective.

Yes. Even after taking 189 it is still worth it. Don't think 127 is just preparation of 189, it is also a valuable class itself.

Getting an A in 54 is far from enough mathematical maturity.

children.subject: (Still OP) I definitely agree Math 54 isn't enough by itself, which is why I'm taking Math 110 as well, which I hope will be fundamental and theoretical enough to serve as a prereq for 189
If you take 110 already, you will find 127 much less worthwhile. Given this you can plan schedule wisely. You will be able to figure out what to do after you finish 110 next semester
Can you elaborate why you think 127 becomes a lot less worthwhile after taking 110?

Value of 127: Maturity of mathematical proof of linalg + Breath and application on EE

Value of 110: Maturity of mathematical proof of linalg + Structured mathematical proofs in context of axiom system
If I'm planning on doing data science in industry, is the only relevant part of 127 the mathematical maturity, which I can also get from 110?

While it is true that 110 makes 127 a bit less worthwhile from the perspective of mathematical maturity, the optimization content in 127 is pretty worthwhile on its own (and would be relevant for data science). The linear algebra in 127 is much more practical than that in 110 imo.
+1. It’s like collecting the reward of LA after 110
Just a follow up to this, does the material in 127 become more digestible/easier to learn after taking math 110?

I would say the material is better reinforced, as 110 gives you another more theoretical perspective. I took both at the same time and found that 127 helped me with 110 more than 110 helped me with 127, just because 127 was much harder, requiring/resulting in more mathematical maturity (imo).

OP here. Probably going to take Math 110 next semester and EECS 127 + CS 189 in Spring 2020 unless there's a strong reason to change my mind. Unfortunately, I don't have any time for the EE 16 series, but I'm hoping other classes can help fill in the gap

Also a note from above: My semesters of 54 +110 didn't stress SVD or PCA but 127 "reteaches" it to you in the first third of the course 

so I felt totally fine doing 127 with 54 + 110 instead of ee16a/b

There was also a diagnostic quiz on the second day of lecture to see if you had enough linear algebra background to succeed in the course and I felt it was no problem with my background.
Would it be alright if I reached out to you via email or on Facebook?

yeah! email me at fmcquarrie3@berkeley.edu

I have a lot to say about these classes so it's easier to type over email.

as a side note: I have a distinctive learning style so what works for me might not work for everybody, but I hope my experiences can help. 

Also, you can take so many courses to prepare for 189 and its still gonna be hard. I've taken so many math/stat courses and I still got WRECKED by the 189 midterm last night :)

It's ok I'm still learning a lot which I really care about, so 189 is still a good class to take and challenge yourself.

I took Math 110 in Fa18 after 54 (no EE16a/b) and found it incredibly valuable - I really enjoy linear algebra and it helped develop my mathematical rigor skills more than 70 did. 

Math 54 + Math110 is enough to go into EE127 - I am in EE127 this semester and felt those two courses were exactly enough preparation needed. 

I also liked taking 127 after math110 because the first third of 127 was linear algebra, but linear algebra concepts that I hadn't yet learned (my sem of 54 and 110 didn't stress SVD, PSD/PD matrices at all), so I was doing a concept that I enjoyed and also still learning new things. 

I am in 127 + 189 (w/ Shewchuk) right now and I kinda like the combo together? It was nice in the first third of each course because both were focusing on linear algebra concepts that the other had covered so it was a nice interplay. I notice that (at least so far) Shewchuck is focusing less on the math concepts of convexity so I haven't encountered any issue taking 127 at the same time 189 (minus the difficulty of balancing the workload of both at the same time). Not sure if this will apply to other professor's version though. 

I hadn't planned on taking 127 to prep for 189 but I am enjoying the course in its own right and feel the material is valuable!

My opinion: Take both 110 and 127.

110 will develop your abstract mathematical linear algebra ability (I didn't realize how abstract we were getting until I compared the content to content of 189+ 127). 

127 will build on some practical applications of your linear algebra skills (and reinforce them) but also introduce you to the concepts of convexity, which is not covered in 110 at all. 

Feel free to ask more questions I am finding both of these courses very valuable!

history.content: Is EECS 127 still a valuable class to take concurrently with 189, or should one really take it before 189. Also, is taking Math 110 and EECS 127 alright if I've already done Math 54
history.subject: EECS 127 before or along with CS 189
